Become a Member Our Partnership with the Womenâ€™s Suffrage National Monument Join us in funding the first U.S. monument dedicated to Womenâ€™s History Support Today An International Organization with Global Impact Learn More Who we are With more than 63,000 members in affiliated clubs in every state , the District of Columbia, and more than a dozen countries, GFWC members work in their own communities to support the arts, preserve natural resources, advance education, promote healthy lifestyles, and encourage civic involvement, issues related to domestic and sexual violence awareness/prevention, and advocating for children. learn more OUR IMPACT General Federation of Womenâ€™s Clubs members vary in age, talents, location, background, and profession, but are united in their dedication to actively improve the lives of others. 63,000+ members in affiliated clubs in every state 2,600 existing volunteer clubs across the globe 130+ founded in 1890, GFWC has over a century of history learn more WHRC: From the Archives September 04, 2025 WHRC: From the Archives A Prize-Winning Centennial Celebration The end of summer means back-to-school season for someâ€¦ but in many American communities, itâ€™s also time for stateâ€¦ August 07, 2025 WHRC: From the Archives An Ode to Summer: Baking with GFWC The WHRC was lucky enough to have two college interns this summer, Sydney Trager and Rileyâ€¦ July 03, 2025 WHRC: From the Archives Researching Settlement Work in the Tennessee Federation The WHRC is delighted to offer our first guest blogger, Cate LiaBraaten! Every donation brings us closer to our goal of restoring our Headquarters faÃ§ade to its full glory, helping repair the iconic white front-facing exterior walls of GFWCâ€™s beloved Headquarters buildings. $70,000 77% Make A gift FEATURED CONTENT GFWC International Day of Service The General Federation of Womenâ€™s Clubs (GFWC) is united in its dedication to volunteer community service. The GFWC International Day of Service brings together clubs from around the world to stand united against domestic and sexual violence. Learn about the 2025 GFWC International Day of Service Signature Program: Domestic and Sexual Violence Awareness and Prevention GFWC creates and leads education, public awareness, and service projects for club members and local citizens at the community level; collaborates with national domestic violence networks and organizations; supports existing activities and established programs; advocates for victims and survivors; and provides educational opportunities to survivors. GFWC aims to be a powerful voice for victims and survivors. Learn More WHRC: Womenâ€™s History and Resource Center Founded in 1984, the GFWC Womenâ€™s History and Resource Center (WHRC) collects, preserves, interprets, and promotes the history of GFWC. The WHRC documents the social and political contributions of GFWC clubwomen from 1890 to the present through the GFWC archives and related special collections. DONâ€T miss this important Training opportunity that makes you eligible for additional training! Date: Tuesday, Sept. 9, at 7 pm ET Join Shot@Life to help give more kids around the world access to lifesaving vaccines. During this 45-minute training specialized for GFWC clubwomen on Tuesday, September 9 at 7pm ET, you will learn about Shot@Life's work as well as tools and tips for advocating to your members of Congress and your communities about global immunization programs. To register, click on the following link: unfoundation.zoom.us/meeting/register/OW9gcSBOSnaYfXV9Py1YIA#/registration By the end of the training, you will be an official Shot@Life Champion, ready to use your voice for the cause. You will also be eligible to join for the virtual Mobilize to Immunize Fall Summit on Thursday, September 18, where you can dive deeper into the issues, learn from experts about the current global health advocacy landscape and tactics, and connect with fellow Champions from across the country in breakout sessions. Sign up today and share this with other GFWC members. #GFWC Advocacy #GFWC #GFWC _HQ #IamGFWC #LivingTheVolunteerSpirit #ShotAtLife #immunization #ImmunizationSavesLives #worldhealthorganization #UnitedNations #GFWC â€¦ See More See Less 3 days ago It's WHRC Wednesday! Next Monday, September 8th, is International Literacy Day. Literacy has been a key focus of GFWC, and our member clubs, since the 19th century: helping every member of our communities, old and young, reach their potential through reading skills and comprehension. During the 1962-1964 administration of GFWC President Margaret Long Arnold, we even sponsored the publication of a manual (with the help of experts at the US Office of Education, forerunner of the Department of Education). Specifically aimed at volunteers, we believed it would help our members dive into "the fight against illiteracy." In a letter urging clubs to purchase the book, Arnold wrote, "You will see that there is a job for all club members at all levelsâ€¦ This is an important project upon which we have embarked to help our fellow citizens help themselves. It is a giant step in the right direction and we must not let our footsteps falter as we face the many problems that will have to be surmounted." ðŸ“’"Your club can spark the fight against illiteracy!" Flyer for the new book "Teaching Adults the Literacy Skills," 1963. PRO 1962-1964 f20 #InternationalLiteracyDay #ClubwomenInHistory #LivingTheVolunteerSpirit â€¦ See More See Less 1 week ago Itâ€™s WHRC Wednesday! To round out our look at the letters received by the GFWC Resolutions Committee in the lead-up to the 1914 convention, here is one of the odder letters in that archival file: an urgent plea from inventor Laura A. McLain of Newark, Ohio, to Jane Addams (yes, that Jane Addams) regarding the dangers of unguarded hatpins. Mrs. McLain received a patent for her new and improved â€œhat-pin guardâ€ in January 1914. Seeing a potential market, or knowing the legislative successes of the Federation (probably both), McLain hoped to persuade attendees of our June 1914 Convention to adopt her invention both in spirit (in the form of a resolution) and in fact (in the form of purchased guards). Her letter claims, â€œthere is no work needed more than to stop the use of the barbarous unprotected hat pinâ€¦if there is any reform work needed more than this, I should be glad to know what it is.â€ Hatpins could indeed be dangerous, both purposefully â€“ see the comments for links regarding the â€œhatpin perilâ€ of the early 20th century, mostly in relation to women using them for self-defense against harassment â€“ and accidentally. But, to be blunt (no hatpin pun intended), there were more pressing items on the GFWC agenda. Sadly for the enterprising Mrs. McLain, it doesnâ€™t seem that the Convention took this problem seriously enough to offer it as a formal resolution. As for Jane Addams, my suspicion is that she never saw this letter; it was probably delivered to the Chicago hotel where the convention was taking place and redirected to the Resolutions committee. But the fact that a non-member addressed a plea to Addams, as a Chicago representative of GFWC, does speak to her renown as both an activist and a clubwoman. ðŸ“· First page of McLain's letter to GFWC via Jane Addams, June 9, 1914. (Full text of the letter in the comments.) Resolutions collection, correspondence, 1914 ðŸ“· Patent no. 1,083,333 granted to Laura A. McLain of Newark, Ohio on January 6, 1914 for a Hat Pin Guard, "a useful and ornamental device which may be slipped over the pointed end of a pin that is projected through the hat to prevent contact of said point with any object." â€¦ See More See Less 2 weeks ago GFWC proudly commemorates the 1920 certification of the 19th Amendment to the Constitution, granting women the right to vote. For more than 135 years, GFWC has advocated for women's rights and for the needs of children, families, and our local communities in the U.S. and around the world. Please make a donation today to help GFWC continue its invaluable work: memberportal.gfwc.org/supportus #GFWC #GFWC _HQ #GFWC Advocacy #LivingTheVolunteerSpirit #IamGFWC #women ssuffrage #19thAmendment #WomensEqualityDay #women #women supportingwomen #children #family â€¦ See More See Less 2 weeks ago Join the GFWC Walk to End Alzheimerâ€™s We all dream of a future when Alzheimer's will no longer destroy our families, our finances, and our futures. But the reality of today is that 1 in 3 older adults dies with Alzheimer's or another dementia. Thanks to our supporters, we're fighting for families today and working toward a future without Alzheimer's by: â€¢  Investing $430 million in over 1,150 active research projects in 57 countries. â€¢  Supporting the nearly 12 million caregivers and the over 7 million Americans living with Alzheimer's with information about care options, caregiver health resources, and digital tools like ALZConnectedÂ®. â€¢  Giving anyone impacted by this devastating disease somewhere to turn in times of need through our free 24/7 Helpline (800.272.3900). How can you help? You can form a Team or join a Team with the Alzheimerâ€™s Association for the Walk to End Alzheimerâ€™s. Please remember to add GFWC to the name of your team so that the funds raised can be attributed to the General Federation of Women's Clubs National Team efforts in our goal to raise $50,000.00 to End Alzheimer's. Any clubs, states, or Regions that walk to End Alzheimerâ€™s are considered a part of the GFWC National Team.  Please note you can join any GFWC Team by donating and/or walking in their walk. Why We Support St. Jude Nearly 100,000 members strong, the General Federation of Women's Clubs is united in its dedication to volunteer community service. While diverse in age, interests, and experiences, all clubwomen are united by a desire to create positive change in their communities. Celebrating more than 125 year of service, GFWC is committed to remain a leading voice in areas where members are active every day. As an organization dedicated to community improvement, they are dedicated to discussing important topics that impact the quality of life for all. The women of the General Federation of Womenâ€™s Clubs (GFWC) have participated in multiple projects that benefit children. Clubwomen have become strong advocates for children by working to: 1) Ensure children are protected from harmful situations 2) Encourage healthy physical and emotional lifestyles 3) Impact policy to improve childrenâ€™s lives As exemplified by their tagline "Living the Volunteer Spirit," GFWC clubwomen transform lives each day, not simply with monetary donations, but with hands-on, tangible projects and volunteer efforts that provide immediate impact. With a grassroots approach that often thinks locally but impacts globally, GFWC remains committed to serving as a force for global good. GFWC is proud to return as National Team for the third year. Long before most military branches opened their doors, women were officially appointed as keepers in the U.S. Lighthouse Service, a proud predecessor to todayâ€™s Coast Guard. These trailblazing women safeguarded our shores, guided sailors home through every storm, and rescued numerous boaters in distress, undoubtedly laying the foundation for centuries of female Coast Guard heroes to come. Letâ€™s celebrate the U.S. Coast Guard and honor the countless women who have served with strength and dedication by supporting the creation of a new national landmark: the National Coast Guard Museum! Boynton Beach takes ownership of historic Woman's Club building Turning Point USA chief Charlie Kirk, a fixture at West Palm Beach summits, killed in Utah News Sports Restaurants Real Estate Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals BOYNTON BEACH Boynton Beach takes ownership of historic Woman's Club building, hoping it can turn profit Jorge Milian Palm Beach Post BOYNTON BEACHÂ â€” The historic Boynton Woman's Club has a new landlord. Ownership of the building, designed by architect Addison Mizner andÂ listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1979, was officially transferred on March 9 to the city from the Boynton BeachÂ Community Redevelopment Agency. The CRA purchasedÂ the building, located at 1010 S. Federal Highway, in 2017 for $110,000 after the ladies of the volunteer Woman's Club were unableÂ to raise the money for necessary restoration. It was appraised last year for just under $630,000. As part of the deal, the CRA will provide the city with annual grants of $250,000 for three years to cover expenses for things like making improvements to match city code andÂ increasingÂ accessibility forÂ visitors. More Boynton: 'We are seen as the punching bag': County's lone Asian American politician fights back against racism More: Boynton bicyclist, 75, was training for 500-mile ride when he was struck, killed by car More: Family, detectives ask for clues in unsolved 2015 Boynton Beach homicide The CRA spent much of the past three years leading its own repair and renovation efforts, including substantial work on a roof damaged by Hurricane Irma. The building was shut down as a result of COVID-19 and has resumed holding events only since January. City officials are confident the Woman's ClubÂ can eventually turn a profit by being rented out for weddings, birthday parties, business conferences and other private uses. During a CRA meeting last May, city administrators estimated the 12,626-square-foot facility could hold 25 weddings a year and generate $50,000 annually. Combined with other special events and feesÂ â€“ including a projected $100,000 from vendorsÂ â€“ the building will attract $361,000 annually in revenue compared to $189,000 in expenses for a net income of $172,000, according to the city. Local residents get a discount on rental charges. Among the expected expensesÂ are $50,000 to hire an event supervisor. "One of the waysÂ to keep the Woman's Club in good repair is to use it, because if itâ€™s not used, you sometimes miss out on something small that leads to a big problem," Mayor and CRA Chairman Steven Grant said. Construction on the building was completed in 1926 and dedicated to Major Nathan S. Boynton, the cityâ€™s founder, in 1932.Â Itâ€™s housed events from World War II-era Red Cross dances to annual scholarship programs and served as the cityÂ library until 1961 and as a hurricane shelter in its early days. The structure isÂ an example of the Mediterranean Revival style of architecture made popular in Palm Beach County by Mizner, arguably the best known American architect of the 1920s. He provided the design to Boynton Beach for free, and the facility is the only Mizner-designed project in South Florida that is open to the public. "Itâ€™s an extremely unique building that weâ€™re very happy to have here in Boynton Beach," Grant said. Boynton has one other nationally registered historic place, the Schoolhouse Childrenâ€™s Museum, which the city owns. Anyone interested in renting the building or its future programming is asked to contact Diane Valenti at 561-742-6756. jmilian@pbpost.com @caneswatch Careers Staff Directory Accessibility Sitemap Legals Public notice certification Our Ethical Principles USA TODAY Network Style Guide Responsible Disclosure Subscription Terms & Conditions Advertiser Acceptance Policy Terms of Service Privacy Policy California Notice at Collection Your Privacy Choices Contact Us Support Local Business Advertise Your Business Promote your Event Buy and Sell Licensing & Reprints Help Center Palm Beach Post Store Subscriber Guide Manage Account Give Feedback Newspapers In Education Newsletters Facebook X eNewspaper Archives Jobs Real Estate Classifieds Shopping 10BEST LocaliQ Digital Marketing Solutions Â© 2025 www.palmbeachpost.com.
